query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Intra due cibi, distanti e moventi 2 d’un modo, prima si morria di fame, 3 che liber’ omo l’un recasse ai denti;
4 sì si starebbe un agno intra due brame 5 di fieri lupi, igualmente temendo; 6 sì si starebbe un cane intra due dame:
7 per che, s’i’ mi tacea, me non riprendo, 8 da li miei dubbi d’un modo sospinto, 9 poi ch’era necessario, né commendo.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Between two foods, distant and moving 2 in the same way, one would die of hunger first 3 before a free man would bring one to his teeth;
4 so would a lamb stand between two ravenous 5 fierce wolves, fearing them equally; 6 so would a dog stand between two does:
7 therefore, if I was silent, I do not blame myself, 8 driven in one direction by my doubts, 9 since it was necessary, nor do I praise myself.
**Old English:**
1 Betwux twæm gereordum, feor and neah, 2 on anlicne wisan, ær gecuren wurde 3 ðæt freo man æt his teðum æt 4 swa sceolde stedeweard betwux twæm wulfum, 5 grimme and grædige, gelice ongitan; 6 swa sceolde hund betwux twæm hindum:
7 forðy, gif ic swugode, ne tæle ic me selfne, 8 fram minum tweonum on an weg gedræfed, 9 ða hit neod wæs, ne ic me næfre herige.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Io mi tacea, ma ’l mio disir dipinto 11 m’era nel viso, e ’l dimandar con ello, 12 più caldo assai che per parlar distinto.
query.result:
**English:**
10 I was silent, but my painted desire 11 was in my face, and the demand with it, 12 hotter far than for distinct speech.
**Old English:**
10 Ic swugode, ac min willa gewat 11 wæs on minum ansyne, and ðæt wilnung mid ðy, 12 hatre mycel ðonne ðurh spræce gesæd.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Tu argomenti: “Se ’l buon voler dura, 20 la vïolenza altrui per qual ragione 21 di meritar mi scema la misura?”.
query.result:
**English:**
19 You argue: “If good will endures, 20 why should the violence of another 21 diminish the measure of my merit?”
**Old English:**
19 ðu secgst: “Gif se goda willa ðurh ðolað, 20 ðonne sceal ðæs oðres mannes unriht 21 ðone mede min minne gemetan?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Ancor di dubitar ti dà cagione 23 parer tornarsi l’anime a le stelle, 24 secondo la sentenza di Platone.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Again, you have reason to doubt 23 that souls return to the stars, 24 according to Plato's opinion.
**Old English:**
22 Eft ðe mæg ðin sefa tweon wesan 23 ðæt ða sawla eft to ðam steorrum cyrrað, 24 swa swa Plato gesette on his lare.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Queste son le question che nel tuo velle 26 pontano igualmente; e però pria 27 tratterò quella che più ha di felle.
query.result:
**English:**
25 These are the questions that in your will 26 point equally; and therefore first 27 I will treat the one that has more gall.
**Old English:**
25 Þas sind ða spæce þe on ðinum willan 26 efnelice stingap; and forðæm ic ær 27 ða secge þe mæste biternes hafað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 D’i Serafin colui che più s’india, 29 Moïsè, Samuel, e quel Giovanni 30 che prender vuoli, io dico, non Maria,
31 non hanno in altro cielo i loro scanni 32 che questi spirti che mo t’appariro, 33 né hanno a l’esser lor più o meno anni;
34 ma tutti fanno bello il primo giro, 35 e differentemente han dolce vita 36 per sentir più e men l’etterno spiro.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Of the Seraphim, the one who soars highest, 29 Moses, Samuel, and that John 30 whom you wish to take, I say, not Mary,
31 have their seats in no other heaven 32 than these spirits who have just appeared to you, 33 nor do they have more or fewer years in their existence;
34 but all of them beautify the first circle, 35 and they have a life of varying sweetness 36 according to how much or how little they feel the eternal breath.
**Old English:**
28 ðæra Serafin se ðe selast wunað, 29 Moyses, Samuel, and se Iohannes 30 ðe ðu wilt niman, ic secge, nis Maria,
31 næbben on oðrum heofenum heora setl 32 ðonne ðas gastas ðe ðe nu æteowdon, 33 ne næbben on heora wæsene ma oððe læsse geara;
34 ac ealle hi fægeriað ðone forman hring, 35 and mislice habbað swetnysse lifes 36 æfter ðæm ðe hi ma oððe læs gefelað ðone ecan gast.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Qui si mostraro, non perché sortita 38 sia questa spera lor, ma per far segno 39 de la celestïal c’ha men salita.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Here they showed themselves, not because this sphere 38 is allotted to them, but to make a sign 39 of the celestial one, which has less ascent.
**Old English:**
37 Hēr hīe him āwægon, nā forðæm ðe hīe ðeos sfēra 38 sȳ līðe, ac for ðǣm ðe hīe woldon tācnian 39 ðā heofonlīcan, ðe hæfð læsse stīgend.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Così parlar conviensi al vostro ingegno, 41 però che solo da sensato apprende 42 ciò che fa poscia d’intelletto degno.
query.result:
**English:**
40 Thus it is necessary to speak to your intellect, 41 because only from a wise man does one learn 42 that which later makes one worthy of understanding.
**Old English:**
40 Þus is niedpearf ðinum ingeþonce, 41 forðæm ðe ðurh snyttro man leornað 42 ðæt ðe syððan bið andgites wyrðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Quel che Timeo de l’anime argomenta 50 non è simile a ciò che qui si vede, 51 però che, come dice, par che senta.
query.result:
**English:**
49 What Timeus argues about souls 50 is not similar to what is seen here, 51 because, as he says, it seems that they feel.
**Old English:**
49 Þæt þe Timeus ymbe sawle smeað 50 nis na gelic þæm þe her gesyne bið, 51 forðæm þe, swa he cwæð, hi þyncað þæt hi felan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 S’elli intende tornare a queste ruote 59 l’onor de la influenza e ’l biasmo, forse 60 in alcun vero suo arco percuote.
query.result:
**English:**
58 If he intends to return to these wheels, 59 the honor of the influence and the blame, perhaps 60 in some true bow of his he strikes.
**Old English:**
58 Gif he wile wendan to ðisum hweole, 59 wuldor ðære gesælda and ðæt gescynd, mæg 60 on sumum his ryhtum bogan beatan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Questo principio, male inteso, torse 62 già tutto il mondo quasi, sì che Giove, 63 Mercurio e Marte a nominar trascorse.
query.result:
**English:**
61 This principle, misunderstood, twisted 62 almost the whole world already, so that Jupiter, 63 Mercury, and Mars it led astray to name.
**Old English:**
61 Þeos frumsceaft, misforstonden, awende 62 nean ealne middangeard geond ða, swa ðæt Iuppiter, 63 Mercurius and Mars to nemnanne forluron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 L’altra dubitazion che ti commove 65 ha men velen, però che sua malizia 66 non ti poria menar da me altrove.
query.result:
**English:**
64 The other doubt which troubles you 65 has less venom, because its malice 66 could not lead you away from me elsewhere.
**Old English:**
64 Seo oðer tweo ðe ðe gedrefeð 65 hafað læsse attre, forðæm ðe his yfelnys 66 ne mæg ðe lædan elles hwergen fram me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Parere ingiusta la nostra giustizia 68 ne li occhi d’i mortali, è argomento 69 di fede e non d’eretica nequizia.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Our justice seems unjust 68 in the eyes of mortals, but this is proof 69 of faith and not of heretical wickedness.
**Old English:**
67 Þynceð unriht ure rihtwisnes 68 on gesyhðe ðæra deadlicra, is geleafan tacn 69 and nis hæresis wælhreownes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Ma perché puote vostro accorgimento 71 ben penetrare a questa veritate, 72 come disiri, ti farò contento.
query.result:
**English:**
70 But so that your understanding can 71 truly penetrate to this truth, 72 as you desire, I will satisfy you.
**Old English:**
70 Ac ðæt ðin andgit cunne 71 ðurhgrundian ðeos soðfæstnysse, 72 swa ðu gewilnast, ic ðe geðafie.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Se vïolenza è quando quel che pate 74 nïente conferisce a quel che sforza, 75 non fuor quest’ alme per essa scusate:
76 ché volontà, se non vuol, non s’ammorza, 77 ma fa come natura face in foco, 78 se mille volte vïolenza il torza.
query.result:
**English:**
73 If violence is when the one who suffers 74 gives nothing to the one who exerts force, 75 these souls were not excused by it:
76 because the will, if it does not want, is not quenched, 77 but does as nature does in fire, 78 if violence twists it a thousand times.
**Old English:**
73 Gif wælhreow is ðonne ðæt ðe ðolið 74 nænig þing ne gesylð ðam ðe hyt wyrceð, 75 ne wæron ða sawla ðurh ðæt alysede:
76 forðæm ðe willa, gif he nelle, ne bið adwæsced, 77 ac wyrð swa swa ðeos gesceaft on fyre, 78 ðeah ðe hyne wælhreow ðusendfealdne gewemde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Per che, s’ella si piega assai o poco, 80 segue la forza; e così queste fero 81 possendo rifuggir nel santo loco.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Therefore, if she bends much or little, 80 she follows the force; and so these wild beasts did, 81 being able to flee into the holy place.
**Old English:**
79 Forðæm, gif heo hire abiehð mycel oððe lyt, 80 heo folgað ðære strengðe; and swa ðas wyrmas dydon, 81 ða ðe ðone halgan stede secean meahton.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Se fosse stato lor volere intero, 83 come tenne Lorenzo in su la grada, 84 e fece Muzio a la sua man severo,
85 così l’avria ripinte per la strada 86 ond’ eran tratte, come fuoro sciolte; 87 ma così salda voglia è troppo rada.
query.result:
**English:**
82 If their will had been whole, 83 as was Lorenzo's on the gridiron, 84 and Mucius' when he was severe to his own hand,
85 thus he would have driven them back along the road 86 from which they had been dragged, as soon as they were loosed; 87 but so steadfast a will is too rare.
**Old English:**
82 Gif him wære hyra willa geweorðen, 83 swa swa Laurentius on ðam grædan dyde, 84 and Mucius ða ða he his agen hand 85 swiðe stranglice geswencte,
86 ða wolde he hi eft gedrifan habban 87 on ðone weg ðanon ðe hi ær lædde, 87 ac swa fæste wilnunge is seldcum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 E per queste parole, se ricolte 89 l’hai come dei, è l’argomento casso 90 che t’avria fatto noia ancor più volte.
query.result:
**English:**
88 And for these words, if you have gathered them 89 as you should, the argument is quashed 90 that would have troubled you many more times.
**Old English:**
88 And for ðisum wordum, gif ðu gerecest 89 swa swa ðu scealt, ðonne bið ðæt cwid aseced 90 ðe ðe scolde derian giet ðus manige siðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Ma or ti s’attraversa un altro passo 92 dinanzi a li occhi, tal che per te stesso 93 non usciresti: pria saresti lasso.
query.result:
**English:**
91 But now another pass blocks your way 92 before your eyes, such that by yourself 93 you would not emerge: you would first grow weary.
**Old English:**
91 Ac nu ðe ys oðer earfoðnes 92 beforan ðinum eagum, ðæt ðu ðurh ðe selfne 93 ne miht ofercuman: ðu wurde ærest gewæht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 A questo punto voglio che tu pense 107 che la forza al voler si mischia, e fanno 108 sì che scusar non si posson l’offense.
query.result:
**English:**
106 At this point I want you to consider 107 that force is mixed with the will, and they make it 108 so that offenses cannot be excused.
**Old English:**
106 On ðisum stede ic wille ðæt ðu ðence 107 ðæt ðæt geweald ðam willan gemenged is, and ða maciað 108 ðæt ða gyltas ne magon beon forgifene.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Voglia assoluta non consente al danno; 110 ma consentevi in tanto in quanto teme, 111 se si ritrae, cadere in più affanno.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Absolute will does not consent to harm; 110 but it consents to it insofar as it fears, 111 if it withdraws, to fall into greater suffering.
**Old English:**
109 Næfre fulfremed nefre nefre ne wile 110 ðæt him mon wyrse gedon wille, 111 ac he ðæs wyrsan wenan sceal.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Però, quando Piccarda quello spreme, 113 de la voglia assoluta intende, e io 114 de l’altra; sì che ver diciamo insieme».
query.result:
**English:**
112 Therefore, when Piccarda speaks of that, 113 she means the absolute will, and I 114 mean the other; so that we both speak truly.
**Old English:**
112 Forðæm, ðonne Piccarda ðæt spricyð, 113 heo ðone fulle willan mæneð, and ic 114 ðone oðerne; swa ðæt we soð sprecað ætgædere.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Cotal fu l’ondeggiar del santo rio 116 ch’uscì del fonte ond’ ogne ver deriva; 117 tal puose in pace uno e altro disio.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Such was the rippling of the holy river 116 that issued from the font where every truth has its source; 117 thus it brought to peace one desire and the other.
**Old English:**
115 Swylc wæs ðæs hâlgan wæteres yðgewinn 116 ðe of ðam wyllan com ðanon eal soð cymð; 117 ðus hit gesette on sibbe ægðer gewill.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 «O amanza del primo amante, o diva», 119 diss’ io appresso, «il cui parlar m’inonda 120 e scalda sì, che più e più m’avviva,
121 non è l’affezion mia tanto profonda, 122 che basti a render voi grazia per grazia; 123 ma quei che vede e puote a ciò risponda.
query.result:
**English:**
118 "O beloved of the first lover, O divine one," 119 I said next, "whose speech floods over me 120 and warms me so that it enlivens me more and more,
121 my affection is not so profound 122 that it suffices to render you grace for grace; 123 but may He who sees and can do so respond to this."
**Old English:**
118 "Eala ðu leof ðæs forman lufian, ðu halige," 119 cwæð ic ða æfter, "ðæs word me oferflowð 120 and gehyð swa ðæt hit me mare and mare geliðfæst,
121 nis min lufe swa deop, 122 ðæt heo mæge ðe ðanc for ðance agyldan; 123 ac se ðe gesihð and mæg ðæron andswarian."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Io veggio ben che già mai non si sazia 125 nostro intelletto, se ’l ver non lo illustra 126 di fuor dal qual nessun vero si spazia.
query.result:
**English:**
124 I see well that our intellect is never satisfied 125 unless the truth enlightens it 126 outside of which no true knowledge extends.
**Old English:**
124 Ic geseo wel ðæt ure mod næfre ne bið saccfull, 125 būton ðæt soð hit onlihte, 126 būton ðæm nænig soðfæstnys ne bið on rume.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Posasi in esso, come fera in lustra, 128 tosto che giunto l’ha; e giugner puollo: 129 se non, ciascun disio sarebbe frustra.
query.result:
**English:**
127 He settles in it, like a wild beast in its lair, 128 as soon as he has reached it; and he can reach it: 129 if not, every desire would be in vain.
**Old English:**
127 He gesette on ðam, swa wildeor on wicum, 128 sona swa he ðærto cumen hæfð; and cuman he ðærto mæg: 129 gif he ðonne ne mæg, ðonne bið ælc wilnung on ydel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Nasce per quello, a guisa di rampollo, 131 a piè del vero il dubbio; ed è natura 132 ch’al sommo pinge noi di collo in collo.
query.result:
**English:**
130 From that, doubt is born, like a new shoot, 131 at the foot of truth; and it is nature's way 132 that it drives us upward, from neck to neck.
**Old English:**
130 Of ðæm bið geboren, swa swa of telgan, 131 æt ðæs soðan fótum ðæt tweon, and hit is gecynde 132 ðæt hit ús hweteð uppan, of healse to healse.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Questo m’invita, questo m’assicura 134 con reverenza, donna, a dimandarvi 135 d’un’altra verità che m’è oscura.
query.result:
**English:**
133 This invites me, this assures me 134 with reverence, lady, to ask you 135 about another truth that is obscure to me.
**Old English:**
133 Þis me laðað, þis me trymð 134 mid arwurðnesse, laf, to ðinum willan, 135 ymbe oðre soðfæstnesse ðe me syndrig sind.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Io vo’ saper se l’uom può sodisfarvi 137 ai voti manchi sì con altri beni, 138 ch’a la vostra statera non sien parvi».
query.result:
**English:**
136 I want to know if a man can satisfy you 137 with vows as he can with other goods, 138 that on your scales they may not seem small.
**Old English:**
136 Ic wille witan gif man mæg ðe geðolian 137 mid gehatum swa swa mid oðrum godum, 138 ðæt hi on ðinre wage ne ðynce lytle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Beatrice mi guardò con li occhi pieni 140 di faville d’amor così divini, 141 che, vinta, mia virtute diè le reni,
142 e quasi mi perdei con li occhi chini.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Beatrice looked at me with her eyes full 140 of sparks of love so divine, 141 that, vanquished, my virtue turned its back,
142 and I almost lost myself with my eyes downcast.
**Old English:**
139 Beatrice me beheold ðurh hire ehnen fulle 140 mid lufe-leomen swa deorwurðlice, 141 ðæt, oferwunnen, min mægen sealde ða rynas,
142 and ic neah me forleas mid ðam ehnen niðer.
